item.description:
Description from the publisher:

The young sorcerer's apprentices have to set forth alone through the dark enchanted forest for their big test. Fortunately clues about the right path appear in the magic ball — but the sorcerer’s apprentices have to be quick and look very closely because the player who can conjure up the clues will move ahead one step closer to their destination. The player who first finds the path to the sorcerer's secret room is the quickest to pass the sorcerer's exam.

In more detail, in 1, 2, 3 – Hex Herbei! the young magicians must be the first to reach the end of the path, and to advance their figure to the next stage of the path, they must spot one of the items on that path in the crystal ball that lies in front of them. Each round, all players grab the crystal ball in front of them, searching to find one of the four items before anyone else can do the same. When a player finds an item, they advance on the board, then all players change seats! Now you're looking for something new as each crystal ball contains only one of the four items shown on each section of the path, which means that you're looking for something new almost every round.

item.description: Slide your pieces across the game board in Skatter and hope to land them in the right holes to score.

To set up Flip'n Chips, pour all of the chips onto the table, then lay them flat. Players take turns flipping chips over to match colors and shapes. Get seven of your matching chips face up and you win!

It has been a year since the five tribes of Stratos began their journey - each carving their own path to prosperity in the fabled land of legend. Plentiful resources have begun appearing along fault lines almost as if they were gifts from beings dwelling in the depths below. The people thought the gifts a blessing but they could not have been more wrong...

Stratos: Light in the Darkness plays as both a themed extension to the original 'Stratos' and as a stand-alone 2-player game. Exciting new challenges await, including Monsters which add a co-operative element to the game. When combined with the original, Stratos: Light in the Darkness can be played with up to 7 players!

Stratos: Light in the Darkness has 5 character classes, each serving a distinct function. Characters move from space to space on a tile-based board which can be arranged randomly or according to set maps. Each character can perform up to 2 unique actions per turn with movement being a repeatable action. Available character actions (dependent on class) include Harvest, Travel, Search, Attack, Shoot, Defend, Cast and Use.

Points are awarded by defeating characters, casting unique spells, discovering treasures, hoarding resources, promoting characters, occupying strategic locations and slaying Monsters! The first player to reach a pre-determined number of Prosperity points (default 10) is declared the winner.

Stratos: Light in the Darkness is a product of Board and Tale Games Inc., a Canadian boardgame publisher based in Hamilton, Ontario.
In Cobra Paw, players take turns rolling the dice — which feature six unique symbols — then race to grab the tile with the matching pattern before anyone else. Whoever grabs six tiles first wins!

item.description: In the word search game Word-a-Melon, players take turns rolling the die, flipping letter chips, and creating words with the revealed letters. Unused letters are flipped face down again, so players need to use their melon to recall which letters are where. In the end, the player with the most chips wins!

item.description: Whim is a risky word game in which location is everything. Players race to find words with letters that they choose, and the letters must appear either at the beginning, in the middle, or at the end of the word based on the die roll that round.

In Akin, players use suction cups to suction up cards on the table that are related — a.k.a., akin — to the card revealed at the start of the round. The first person to suction up two related cards wins the round, and whoever has won the most rounds after ten rounds wins the game.

In Pile-Up Rush, two players (or teams, if you desire) compete to place odd items on a shared platform, trying not to knock the entire pile over. When a player makes the stack fall, the opponent chooses one of their pieces and keeps it, then they play another round. If you manage to place all of your pieces in the tower, then you get to keep one of the opponent's pieces and start another round.

The first player or team to capture four pieces wins!

item.description:
In Star Plus, players want to rid themselves of cards, but they can't just play anything that they want. No, the cards much be played in turn from 1-12 into the center of the table, then players start with 1 again. You can play a single card that matches the number that should be played on your turn, or you can play multiple cards that sum to the number needed. If you can't play the required number, then you need to draw cards from the deck.

If someone plays three or more cards at the same time — a star boom! — then the next player must play a star boom as well or else draw cards.

When someone voids their hand, players tally their points for cards played.

item.description:
What if the Japanese had landed at Midway?

A Defiant Stand is a hypothetical game exploring what might have happened if the Japanese won the naval battle of Midway and carried out their plans to invade the islands.

Ziplock game, includes 11*17 mapsheet with rules, and 5/8" counters.

Players will need a standard deck of playing cards and one six-sided die to play the game.

Also includes a small expansion scenario for the TPS game The Battle of Midway 1942 AD (1 page of color rules and additional counters)

Description from the publisher:

In Derelict, you are a Space Marine detailed to protect a science team. This team has discovered an artifact orbiting Taurus III, a distant planet located millions of light years from Earth. Initially, there was no sign of anything wrong.

The artifact changed that.

You watch, horrified, as the scientists you swore to protect quickly turn into the stuff of nightmares. The infected crewmembers grow massive scythe-like claws where their arms used to be, razor sharp fangs in place of teeth, and horns now protrude through the skin all over their tortured bodies. These poor souls now only have a singular mission: kill anything in their path.

As the last healthy human aboard, you need to focus on surviving long enough to get the hell out of here!

Derelict is a game for 2-5 players divided into two asymmetrical teams. One player is the human, tasked with restoring the derelict space ship to working order and escaping an untimely end. The other team plays as the infested, who make up the remainder of the players, and have only one goal: kill the human player at all costs!

BACKGROUND
The year is 1793. France cowers under the Reign of Terror, and not even the innocent are safe from the Committee of Public Safety and their precious guillotine. In the midst of this turmoil, one man uses courage and cunning to fight the brutality: The Scarlet Pimpernel.

Along with his League of followers, The Scarlet Pimpernel rescues the innocent from under the very noses of the Committee, leaving behind only a card showing a small pimpernel flower. The man behind the rescues, Englishman Sir Percy Blakeney, must keep his identity a secret from all but his closest associates.

In The Scarlet Pimpernel, you play as members of the league helping the Scarlet Pimpernel accomplish seven missions, rescuing the innocent from the guillotine. No mission will be as important as the last, for you save the young Dauphin, heir to the French throne, by whisking him away to Vienna.

OBJECTIVE
In The Scarlet Pimpernel, players reveal a mission card as the “current mission.” Each mission card has a location and a required number of supporters and resources.

As a member of the League of the Scarlet Pimpernel, you help carry out missions by securing the route and location, obtaining the required number of supporters and resources (horses, carts, papers, and disguises), and filling the five mission spaces. This task is done by placing your cubes in various locations on the board to score points. Although players work together to accomplish missions, only the player with the highest score at the end of the game will become the Scarlet Pimpernel’s most trusted advisor.

GAMEPLAY
Gameplay starts with the player who has the first player marker and proceeds clockwise. On your turn, you must either TAKE AN ACTION or PASS. You may additionally USE A REST CUBE after your initial action. The round ends when each of the five mission spaces has a cube on it, OR all players have passed in succession. You then move on to completing the mission.

On your turn, you must take an action or pass. Actions available to you on your turn include the basic action on your player tile OR actions listed on any ONE Special Favor tile you have collected. The basic action on your player tile allows a choice between two actions: Move Your Pawn or Place a Cube. Special favor tiles give you two actions denoted by the “+” symbol.

ABOUT SPECIAL FAVORS
When a cube is first placed in any of the six planning areas the player placing the cube takes the corresponding special favor tile and attached special favor card and places it to the right of his or her player tile. The characters on the tiles you possess grant you “special favors”. You may use the actions listed on the attached special favor card.

END OF ROUND / GAME
Play continues until each of the five mission spaces has a cube on it OR all players have passed in succession. When this happens you immediately complete the current mission. After the seventh mission is completed, the player with the most points wins!

item.description:
A classic trick-taking, bid-making card game for contemplative players. This medieval-themed game combines elements of collusion, misdirection, risk taking and deduction. Successful players must manage the tension and uncertainty surrounding 4 Specialists, including the powerful Raven.

The game is played with 56 suited cards — Shields, Swords, Axes, and Waters numbered 1 (low) to 14 (high) and 4 special cards (specialists). Each hand features a different trump suit. Players must sacrifice cards from their hands to bid the number of tricks they will take. Each suit conveys a bid value: 0, 1, 2, or 3. The suit (not the rank) of the cards chosen determines how many tricks the player must take. Score 1 point per trick taken, plus a bonus for an exact bid.

The specialists are: 

 Raven — the highest trump
 Wolf — the highest non-trump
 Shaman — a half-step higher than the card it immediately follows
 Dwarf — the lowest card




Each player tries to take (win) the exact number of tricks bid. Deception and collusion are allowed and include saying: how many tricks you bid; what cards you hold; that you want a particular trick; that you won’t take a trick; and lying about any or all of these things. You can say what you like, but you cannot show your cards before you play them.

Card play mechanics are typical for the trick-taking family of games: The player left of the dealer leads. Play proceeds clockwise. A player who can follow suit must either (1) follow suit or (2) play a specialist. A player who cannot follow suit may play any card.

The player with the most points after 8 hands wins. In case of a tie, the player (of those tied) who earned the most bonuses is the winner.

Simple roll-and-move game of the Game of Goose variety, probably sold in the 1940s or 1950s. Two Dutch children find a giant clog in the attic and set out on a circular trip down a canal, using the clog as a boat. While the kids mostly want to take their time sightseeing and collecting some choice tulips, the goal for the players appears to be to return home as quickly as possible. Various spaces contain the usual instructions to take a detour or shortcut, move a number of spaces ahead or back, or lose a turn.

In Topito, players manipulate the circus animals and workers — represented by giant wooden blocks — to complete objective cards in their hand. The game includes a number of circus rings in which activities take place, and on a turn a player adds a block to a stack or moves part of a stack onto another stack. If any player, whether active or not, has one of their objective cards met by this move, then they reveal it and draw a new card. If a player drops a block, they must discard a previously met card as a penalty.

The first player to have seven cards in front of themself wins!

item.description:
Description from the publisher:

We are proud to present our game "The Great Wall of Mexico" with your favorite, and maybe not-so-favorite characters. This is a game of fun and surprises, and an epic battle to build or destroy a wall between Mexico and the United States of America.

More than anything else, this is a game full of humor that will make you and your friends laugh. This is a simple game, and you don't have to know anything about or even care about politics to enjoy this game.

The game starts with a wall half built (or half destroyed if you will). If all the bricks are in place - team orange wins. If all the bricks are gone - team green wins.

The bricks are added or removed after every round, depending on which team wins. The card values are added together and if the score is above zero 0 the green team wins and removes a brick. If not - the orange team does and adds one.

In Yummy Yummy Pancake, you're trying to identify pancakes in a frying pan, but were you paying enough attention to know what's there?

On a turn, a player lays out eight face-up tokens in a frying pan, and all other players get to see the toppings on these pancakes. Then the active player attempts to flip as many pancakes as possible. (If they fail to flip more than two, the player can try again. If any pancakes leave the pan, they're returned to the pan face up.)

After flipping, the active player chooses a face-down pancake and a player. If this player can identify what's on the other side, they claim this pancake; otherwise the flipper keeps it. The flipper can continue to challenge players to remember pancakes or end their turn, in which case the next player refills the pan to eight face-up pancakes and takes their turn.

Once the pancake supply runs out, whoever has the most pancakes wins!

item.description:
Game contents:
4 boards 25 Instruction Cards 48 Walkers in 4 different colors Instruction page in Hebrew and English

The game's objective:
To be the first player who accumulates 6 Walkers in his chosen color.

What is the game's contribution to us and to our children?
Playing this game strengthens our thinking process and perceptivity skills, it also improves our hand movements, its speed and the attention to small details, and finally it creates a colorful and familial experience with great fun. 
 Strengthens thinking process…
Improves hand movements and speed…
Ready, set…
And here we go…

—description from the publisher

"Great fun for all the family all the year oval."

In The Aussie Rules Football Game two coaches roll a die to move the football around the field. Scoring is in the fashion of Australian Rules Football, 6 points for a goal, 1 point for a behind. The game is played over four quarters each of five minutes duration, the team that scores the most points wins.

Codenames: Marvel combines the hit social word game Codenames, while featuring characters and locations from the Marvel Universe including, Spider Man, Guardians of the Galaxy, The Avengers and Doctor Strange. Opposing teams, S.H.I.E.L.D. and Hydra, compete to be the first to identify all of their team’s ‘field agents’ from 25 Code cards displayed in a 5x5 grid. Code cards contain pictures on one side and words on the other.

In Codenames, two teams compete to see who can guess all of their words correctly first — but those words are hiding in plain sight in a 5x5 grid that includes the words of the other team, neutral words, and an assassin that will cause you to lose the game immediately if you guess it. One person on each team is a spymaster and only these two know which words belong to each team. Spymasters take turns giving one-word clues that can point to multiple words on the board. Their teammates try to guess words of the right color while avoiding those that belong to the opposing team — and everyone wants to avoid the assassin.

item.description:
In Codenames, two teams compete to see who can guess all of their words correctly first — but those words are hiding in plain sight in a 5x5 or grid that includes the words of the other team, neutral words, and an game over card that will cause you to lose the game immediately if you guess it. One person on each team is a spymaster and only these two know which words belong to each team. Spymasters take turns giving one-word clues that can point to multiple words on the board. Their teammates try to guess words of the right color while avoiding those that belong to the opposing team — and everyone wants to avoid the game over card. This version also comes with 4x4 grid cards with no game over spot to make it more accessible for families and children.

The Disney Family Edition of Codenames combines the hit social word game with some of Disney’s most beloved properties from the past 90 years. Including both pictures and words, it’s family fun for Disney fans of all ages.Codenames: Disney Family Edition keeps the Codenames gameplay, while featuring characters and locations from over 90 years of Disney and Pixar films..

item.description:
Playing with sticky tongues has never been more fun than what you'll find in Sticky Chameleons!

Each player has a long sticky "tongue", and the table is covered with six types of insect tiles in six colors, along with a few fly tokens. To start a round, someone rolls the two dice — one showing a color, the other an insect — then everyone rushes to "grab" the appropriately colored insect tile by slapping it with their tongue. Tiles will go flying! The round doesn't end until someone removes the tile from their tongue and holds the tile in their hand. This player scores a point, then you do it all again. Whoever scores the predetermined number of points first wins!

item.description:
Do you know the legend of the cherry tree that blossomed every ten years? The story goes that once every decade, the cherry tree would shroud itself in beautiful flowers during the first days of spring. Thousands of buds grew on its branches and stretched elegantly toward the sky before becoming magnificent flowers of inestimable quality.

When the flowers on the cherry tree begin to fall softly to the ground, you rush to collect them before they wither: The one who can gather the most flowers will have their wish granted by the cherry tree. But if you are too greedy, the cherry tree will find you unworthy of its gift, and you will lose the chance to make your dream come true...

The flowers on the cherry tree have begun their delicate fall and are ready to be collected. Each turn, draw one or more flowers from the bag and try to gather as many as possible without being too greedy. At the end of your turn, put your flowers either in front of your screen to gain victory points based on your sets of flowers, or behind your screen to gain victory points by having the largest groups of flowers.

The player who has the most victory points at the end of The Legend of the Cherry Tree that Blossoms Every Ten Years wins.

Description from the publisher:

The era of black gold is over. An alternative to oil has existed for centuries: CANNABIS.

You find unoccupied land where CANNABIS grows in abundance. You purchase your first tractors right away. Your crops allow you to build factories that process the CANNABIS into several products. These products lead to contracts that bring in gold.

Beware of criminals who want to farm your CANNABIS. Protect yourself with the help of police.

EXPAND DESCRIPTION : 
Buy land to sow cannabis seeds and harvest cannabis. Build factories to make products. Transport the products with trucks to win cards. Each card equals one gold coin. The winner is the first player who collect 4 gold coins.

item.description:
The Expanse, a board game based on the Syfy television series of the same name, focuses on politics, conquest and intrigue similar to the board game Twilight Struggle, although with a shorter playing time. The card-driven game uses key images from the show, along with action points and events that allow players to move and place "Fleets" and "Influence".

In more detail, players represent Earth's UN forces, the military of Mars, the rebels of the O.P.A., and the mysterious corporation Protogen Inc. Each player has special abilities that must be maneuvered to gain advantage. Players increase their control over the solar system using characters and events from the universe of The Expanse.

item.description:
From publisher site:

Fast action, as cops patrol the city on a crime wave alert!

With cops playing as pieces, players search for clues to capture 9 criminals on the WANTED list. Clues found on patrol are pegged on the Big City game board. 1st to capture 3 robbers is TOP COP.

Synopsis:
On your turn, if there are not 3 "WANTED Posters" (cards) displayed, you draw one from the tray. There must always be 3 WANTED Posters displayed at all times during the game. You move your piece along the board, collecting clues on the spaces where you land, and match the clues up with items from the WANTED Posters. Once you have collected all 3 clues from one of the Posters, you have caught the criminal in that poster. The first player to capture 3 criminals is the TOP COP.

HOOK: Tile placement/area control game for 2-4 with a retro videogame flair, all in a super-portable package.

DESCRIPTION: In every classic JRPG, the heroes encountered a mysterious stranger, who gave them a map to a dungeon, and stocked them with potions, keys, and other provisions. But how was the map drawn? How did the wise stranger learn of all these dire warnings? In Overworld, you are the hero's mysterious mentor. All those years before you sent the hero to the underworld, you mapped the Overworld!

By laying tiles, you will seek to claim regions of Forests or Mountains with your Bird meeples, and regions of Reefs or Whirlpools with your Ship meeples. When the tiles form a hole in the world, the player who explored the most tiles there will place a Dungeon Door meeple into the hole.

Can you foresee uncertain spots in the geography, indeterminate in the distance? Will you uncover a dungeon... or wander the repeating pixel textures forever?

GAMEPLAY: Players in Overworld will take turns placing L-shaped tiles, one at a time, drawn from a bag. Place it land-side up or water-side up, but water and land may not be adjacent. Or instead, play a Coast tile that connects land to water. When an empty gap is enclosed with tiles, the birds and ships which can enter the gap, without leaving their terrain type, will compete to let their player place a Dungeon Door there.

The player whose Dungeon Door meeples are the farthest apart has discovered the largest and most valuable dungeon!

They have to put cards face up to build their planetary colonies, get spaceships from the market, use action cards from their hand to fight and use their habilities from their races cards.

The player who reaches 12 units of pentanium wins the game. This pentanium parts are given for the played cards, planets conquered and satelites owned.

item.description:
The world is within your grasp! Can you take it?

Diabolical! is a topsy-turvy tabletop game where you play a supervillain trying to take over the world! To do so, you'll need to complete objectives, called Schemes, to execute the most nefarious plan among your evil compatriots. By effectively managing your resources and commanding your minions to do your bidding, the world will surely be in your grasp!

In Diabolical!, players simultaneously issue Commands to build resources and work toward completing Schemes. Working on Schemes earns a player Victory Points, and completing a Scheme earns a player bonus Victory Points as well as additional rewards. Players attempt to maximize their scheme points each round by effectively anticipating their opponents' actions to complete the most schemes possible.

Players have access to special abilities they can use to disrupt their opponents' plans, or to push themselves toward victory faster!

Emblems: NHL is a set-collecting and trick-taking — or hat trick-taking, wink wink — card game that focuses on the grouping of NHL teams and logos. Players call out attributes of specific logos – such as year, Stanley Cups, or colors – and collect as many cards as possible. They can earn additional points along the way by using special in-game and end-game bonus cards that will boost their total score. The player with the highest score wins.

link.value: Games by the Game Artisans of Canada

item.description:
Description from te publisher:

Intrepid explorers have landed on a lost island in search of fabulous diamonds! Setting out from their base camp, the explorers hack their way into the jungle in search of the lost gems but will they get attacked by vicious dinosaurs first?

Diamonds and Dinosaurs is a game for 1-5 players where players search a dangerous jungle made from a deck of cards. Depending on the suit played, either a valuable diamond is revealed, a dangerous dinosaur appears, or the player gains a weapon token into their arsenal to help them hack through the jungle or fight off dinosaurs. The player must roll a d12 to determine which jungle spaces are value for movement. Weapon tokens can be added to your dice roll to increase the number. However, fail a roll and your turn is over. The custom "dinosaur die" can make more diamonds appear, move the existing dinosaurs through the jungle or even repopulate the dinosaurs back to the playfield!

These hungry dinosaurs will take an opportunity to bite at you, so be careful where you end your movement! If you get bit, you lose health. If you lose six health, drop your diamonds and return to base camp. Base camp protects players from dinosaurs as well as mystic statues found in the jungle. Or you might find the hidden temple which houses untold riches... and danger! The first player to collect six diamonds wins the game!

A quantum vortex is rearranging reality... history and fantasy are being jumbled together and somebody needs to untangle the mess! You must find the lost people and creatures then get them to follow you back to their homes. Lead enough followers to safety and you might just be able to destroy the vortex and rescue reality!

Follow is a tile/card matching game based on strategy and luck.
Players create a different board each time by joining together the hex-tiles (111mm max. width) as the game progresses. Each hex shows a different location and in each location there is a 'follower' card (45x63mm).

The locations and characters are well known from history or fantasy but are randomly mixed. The objective is to lead these famous faces to their specific places. For example; you could find a bewildered Dracula in the Wild West and lead him through Ancient Egypt and Camelot to reach his Transylvanian home.

The rules provide a choice of actions each turn, such as exploring new locations and stealing followers from other players as well as the opportunity to have several turns in a row, allowing players to plan strategies.

The followers and locations are colour-coded as yellow, green, blue, purple and red. To win the game a player has to return one follower of each colour to the safety of their specific locations. Upon achieving this feat the player must then succeed a dice roll called the 'Gizmotron roll' in order to reset reality and therefore be declared as the winner.

An eight page (A5) 'Instruction Manual' gives rules for 2 to 6 players aged 8 to adult. A standard game comprises 30 'follower' cards, 30 corresponding location hex-tiles, 6 'vortex' hex-tiles and lasts from 20 to 60 mins, depending on the number of players. The game is made quicker and easier by reducing the number of follower cards involved, along with their location hexes.

Take and trade commodities in the Baltic Sea to acquire more power than your opponents in the main cities of the 13th century!

At the beginning of each round in Riga, commodity cards are randomly grouped into packages with a minimum base value. Their values vary from 2 to 5. Buildings (cards) are placed on the table, too.

Each player takes two turns per round, the first in clockwise order, the second one counterclockwise. Your turn starts with choosing a group of commodity cards OR one building from the display in the middle of the table. Then you may build up to three buildings from your hand. To build, you must pay the costs by discarding your commodities. Depending on where you build (with the color of the building indicating the city), your commodities have a different value. Usually the commodity has a base value, but in every city, one commodity is not wanted at all and another one is more expensive. In Gdansk, for example, you cannot pay with grain, but glass has a value +2. The buildings show victory points and persons. They also have different features to help you get more commodities, create more victory points, or build more easily by giving money per merchant on your cards.

Riga continues the series of small games from Ostia in the Baltic Sea following Visby and Tallinn.

item.description:
Through tactics and karma to wealth and fame...

In 16th century India, the powerful empire of the Great Moguls rises between the Indus and the Ganges rivers. Taking on the role of rajas and ranis – the country's influential nobles – players in Rajas of the Ganges race against each other in support of the empire by developing their estates into wealthy and magnificent provinces. Players must use their dice wisely and carefully plot where to place their workers, while never underestimating the benefits of good karma. Success will bring them great riches and fame in their quest to become legendary rulers.

item.description:
As the shieldwalls clash, ravens fly overhead and lurk where the gory carnage is at its greatest. Break your opponent’s shieldwall before your own army loses heart and flees. Victory shall belong to the most cunning warlord, whose name shall be written into the Sagas.

Battle Ravens is a game of Viking Age warfare: a brutal clash of strength, cunning and luck, where subtlety and nuance are neither welcome or commonplace. You need to out-think and out-fight your opponent to win the battle. You do so by choosing whether to command your battle line to attack, defend, or redeploy, through clever use of action points. Combat is resolved by the roll of dice, and armies consist of Hirdmen (armoured warriors), Bondi (unarmoured warriors), and Thralls (cowardly but useful skirmishers!).

- Description from the publisher

name.value: Rick and Morty: Anatomy Park – The Game

item.description:
Description from the publisher:

Based on the hilarious "Anatomy Park" episode, each player in Rick and Morty: Anatomy Park attempts to construct the world's greatest theme park inside of a homeless guy named Reuben. Players build while battling both monstrous diseases and fellow park-builders with creative differences concerning how the park should be laid out. The object of the game is to score points by placing your park tiles into the best spots within the body. Move your character pawn around the park to scout out the best locations and stay away from (or shoot) the monster diseases that will pop up and cause chaos. Whoever has the most victory points wins and is the master builder of Anatomy Park!

name.value: Imperium Chronicles: Theater of Operations – Boarding Actions

item.description:
Theater of Operations: Boarding Actions portrays tactical combat between boarding parties attacking enemy ships in the Imperium Chronicles universe.

One player takes the role of the Imperium while the other player controls the Magna Supremacy. The game can be played using individual scenarios or players may choose to use resource points to “buy” their forces before the game begins. Units include regular crew members, security, marines, heavy marines, and turrets.

Theater of Operations: Boarding Actions is designed with ease of play in mind, including rules that are simple to learn and execute.

Features:

 Three full-color ship maps in 1" scale
 Five general unit types including regular crew, security, marines, heavy marines, and turrets
 Three special attributes: Leader, Medic, Demolition
 Individual weapon types including small arms, shotguns, hand grenades, and grenade launchers
 800+ ship counters (full-strength & wounded sides)
 Straight-forward rules for fast gameplay

The greatest nation in the world is in decline. A wealthy oligarchy has all the money, land, and power, leaving the masses to starve and struggle under the weight of oppressive debts. A bitter, partisan feud between polar opposites – liberal and conservative – finds no room for compromise. Government, once conducted with dignity and restraint, becomes a dangerous game of brinksmanship and obstructionism. The very foundations of the republic are undermined by demagogues and dictators, using civil unrest to seize power. Opponents are marginalized or made to disappear, with even murder given the veneer of legitimacy retroactively. The result is the collapse of the old order, and the establishment of new, totalitarian regime, with the populace often at the mercy of madmen and idiots, the venal and the vainglorious.

We are talking, of course, about the Roman Republic. OPTIMATES ET POPULARES is a political game for two players, in which players fight for the primacy and dominance of their ideology. The Populares ("populists") pursue a liberal and egalitarian agenda that seeks to better the lives of the poor through measures such as land redistribution, debt relief, and welfare programs. The Optimates (or "best men") aim to thwart this progress, maintaining the traditional rights and privileges of the wealthy elites. Both players seek to win elections and pass laws, and to prevent their opponents from doing the same, using every tool at their disposal - building alliances through influential Senators, buying loyalties, inciting mob violence, and proscription - state-sanctioned murder.

Central to the game is Political Will. Each action you take will cost you some Political Will. The more you accomplish, the more anger it incites in the opposition and its supporters - and so, each action you take also cedes Political Will to your opponent. This creates a dynamic tension in which each player must balance pursuit of his own goals against the backlash that's just around the corner. Each law you pass will also have subtle (and not-so-subtle) effects on the People of Rome and the Senate, building or eroding support for your overall platform. It's a careful balancing act - a vicious teeter-totter - a knife-fight on a tightrope.

Description from the publisher:

Based on the Wargame Adaptive Ruleset (WAR), AVP: Unleashed is a fast-paced, tactical game that pits the forces of two or more players against each other. From small skirmish fights of a squad or two to large-scale battles, AVP: Unleashed can be played in an endless number of ways.

This book includes:

 132 pages of full color rules and background material on each unit.
 Tournament-ready missions and countless ways to play them.
 Escalation rules for campaigns
 3 full factions' Army Lists: The brave forces of the USCM, the elite Predators, and the overwhelming Aliens

link.value: Alien vs Predator: The Hunt Begins

item.description:
Description from the publisher:

A clock shows 4:55am

Yard Boss
“I see a couple new faces here today. Nice. So Here's the drill. Contracts come in for freight and passengers every morning starting at 5am. Trains need to be loaded and out of here by 5:30. You have exactly 30 mins to complete your tasks. It is YOUR job to see that ALL contracts are fulfilled. GOT IT?!?”

“More than that, make sure you make the railyard money or you are sacked! Every locomotive, and car you use needs to be fully loaded, or it will cost you your job. And one more thing, don’t overload my trains. Locomotives can only pull so much. You blow one of my engines and I will become seriously unpleasant.”

“Any questions?”

"No?"

“Excellent"

“One more thing to remember, as departure time draws nearer and you see you don’t have enough capacity to fill all your contracts, you can always sub them out to one of these mates standing next to you. You may not get paid for that contract, but it won't count against you when the whistle blows. You and I get paid when the contracts get filled so make sure there are no contracts in your hand when the whistle blows.“

“Now get out there and make me some money!”

Gameplay is as follow:
Players start with 10 train cards. Each turn they can either draw 3 cards or play 3 cards. In order to play cards, you must first play a locomotive and coal car. Then additional car and cargo can be played. The correct train car needs to be played in order to place cargo and cargo is the only way to make money. In the end, if time and running out and there is cargo you cant play, then subcontract it onto another player's train. You may not get the money for it, but it wont cost you double in the end. You also might just fill a spot on an opponent's train that they needed.

Description from the publisher:

The sea is too small for two! Expand your krill kingdom and stop other krill clans to become the only ruler of the sea. There can be only one krill king! However, be aware of the pitfalls of the sea! Cruel creatures, unexpected natural events and dangerous vessels can stand on your way to victory!

Krill is a tile-laying strategy board game where the players take turns to place tiles on the game board. As they do so, their krill swarms emerge and grow. Players can place krill swarm tiles to build their krill swarm and to block other players, they can play special tiles to move, rotate or remove krill swarm tiles from the game board, or they can place krill knights instead to protect their krill swarm from the effects of special tiles. At the end of the turn, the players can relocate their krill knights for the best protection or suit their strategy.

The game is over when the whole game board is full, and it's scoring time. Each player scores one victory point for each krill swarm segment connected with at least one of his krill knights.

name.value: Forbidden: A Mature Party Game for Immature People

item.description:
Description from the publisher:

As we like to say, this game is not for the easily embarrassed, often offended, or humorless among you… Forbidden is a game for those of us that revel in watching our friends squirm, get flustered, and curse loudly. If this is you, then welcome to Forbidden!
 All players split into teams and in each round one player will try to get his team to guess the target word, without using any of the Forbidden words listed on the card. If the player can get their teammates to guess the target word they score a point and move on to the next card, the object is to score as many points as possible in the time allowed. However, if the player messes up and uses a Forbidden word or says any part of the target word then the card and the point go to the other team. Additionally, if you are caught using any of the Forbidden words then you must draw a Forbidden card, these can be beneficial, but usually they are an additional obstacle that you must deal with on your next turn. 
 We also have four types of special cards included in the deck-
 Skip- Allows you to skip past a difficult card without a penalty or without the other team getting a point.
 Steal- This card allows your team to jump in for a round and try to guess the target words while the other team gives clues. Any words that you guess first will score a point for your team.
 F@*K You- Use this card to pass the most challenging cards to the other team, they must start their turn with that card.
 Wild- This card works as any one of the other cards, your choice!
 That’s it, that’s all you need to know to play the game, simple right? However every game is unique based on who you play with and with a massive deck of Forbidden cards to play through you should expect countless hours of laughing at your friends. 
 Forbidden- A mature game, for immature people

Description from the publisher:

Despite what appear to be very simple golfer keywords, HMG realistically captures the real-life abilities of real pro golfers. The top golfers will dominate your tourney events. The big hitters will time and again launch monster shots that put them in position to break par. The "golden" putters make the clutch putts that others miss. Those who have demonstrated their prowess out of the bunker or rough will have you nodding in admiration as they do the same thing on your tabletop! And, just like in real golf, intangibles matter, too! Experience, mood, momentum—there are keywords for those, too, with both positive and negative ramifications. Every golfer gets his own unique, individual card, a compilation of all the keywords applicable to his game.

History Maker Golf: 2017 Pro National Golf Card Set
History Maker Golf: All-Time Great Golfers Card Set
History Maker Golf: Course Collection Eight

History Maker Golf: Course Collection Nine
History Maker Golf: Course Collection One
History Maker Golf: Course Collection Seven

History Maker Golf: Course Collection Two

item.description:
CHALLENGE BETWEEN TWO SUSHI CHEF!
 Take up your chopsticks!
Who will be the quickest Sushi Chef?
 The wooden ingredients of Makemaki are made of wood coming from eco-friendly forestry in respect of the natural and social environment. 
 Makemaki is a safe, eco-friendly game made with nontoxic paint and made in Italy
 COMPONENTS:
48 coloured wooden ingredients to make 6 maki
2 green felt placemats
2 pairs of bamboo chopsticks
33 cards with compositions of the recipes and instructions
 NR. OF PLAYERS: 2
 RECOMMENDED AGE: 6 +

INSTRUCTIONS:
A test of skill and speed between two Sushi Chefs. Set a placemat, 2 chopsticks and half the available ingredients in front of you and draw a card with a recipe from the pack. The challenge begins! The winner is the first chef to make, on their placemat, all the maki on the card using only the chopsticks! .

A GAME OF CANTONESE RICE - Get your chopsticks ready!
 The wooden ingredients of A game of Cantonese rice are made of wood coming from eco-friendly forestry in respect of the natural and social environment.
 A game of Cantonese rice is a safe, eco-friendly game realised with nontoxic paint and made in Italy
 COMPONENTS:
1 large bowl
2 small bowls
250 wooden kernels (rice)
21 green wooden spheres (peas)
20 pink wooden cubes (ham)
20 yellow wooden discs (eggs)
2 pairs of bamboo chopsticks** 
NR. OF PLAYERS: 2
 RECOMMENDED AGE: 5 +

INSTRUCTIONS:
Each players receives a bowl and a pair of chopsticks, while the ingredients (rice, peas, ham and eggs) are mixed together in the big bowl, which must be placed between the two players.
Ready, steady, go!
Using only the chopsticks, each player tries to take as many coloured ingredients as possible from the big bowl to put them in their small bowl. The winner is the player who gets the most coloured ingredients!

TURTLECHALLENGE - Unbelievably agile turtles take on amazing challenges!
 Whose turtle will get closest to the Giant Rock? Whose tower will be the tallest? 
 The turtles are made of wood coming from eco-friendly forestry in respect of the natural and social environment. 
 Turtle challenge is a safe, eco-friendly game realised with nontoxic paint and made in Italy.
 
COMPONENTS:
8 wooden turtles in two colours (4 green, 4 orange)
1 wooden rock 
 NR. OF PLAYERS: 2
 RECOMMENDED AGE: 4 +
 INSTRUCTIONS:
turtle run: Test your dexterity! Slide your turtle as close to the Giant Rock as possible in this new take on bowls. The closest one wins!
turtle tower: Test your balancing skills! Try to place the most turtles on top of the Giant Rock. The winner is the player who makes the highest tower without it falling!

The ruling house of the empire is in decline and in their weakness an opportunity presents itself. The throne is within the grasp of any rival faction bold and cunning enough to grab power for themselves.

However, this is a nuanced conflict, one where diplomacy cuts just as sharply as the weapons of an army, but half as so as the assassin’s blade. There are wheels within wheels and machinations beyond your view.

Players represent powerful houses, each seeking to be in ascent of the throne. Every player has the same six cards, which provide Strength, Favor, Victory Points, and bonuses. Unfortunately, the path forward is shrouded in fog, forcing players to manage the uncertainty of the times.

Every round, players draft a hand of cards, choosing a mix of their cards, their opponents’, and powerful Events. The key is building a viable strategy with your own cards and events, while denying key cards from your opponents. Then, cards are played face down one at a time to the Planets. Limited information about each card is disclosed. Players are forced to make decisions with imperfect information gained during the draft and by reading your opponents. Finally, the cards are revealed and resolved. In most cases, players want to be the Strongest or Favored faction to score Victory Points.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
In June, 1812, Napoleon invaded Russia with over 500,000 troops, not so much to "conquer" anything but really intending to fight on big battle (like Austerlitz) and then dictate terms. Unfortunately, the Russian armies did not comply.

He finally got a big battle at Smolensk, which could be called a French victory...except the Russian armies just retreated and burned. Now under the command of (recalled from retirement) Marshal Kutuzov, the army made a stand near the small village of Borodino, which had only marginal useful defensive terrain but was the best place to stop the French before Moscow.

After two days of skirmishing and probing, the major battle took place Monday, September 7. About 250,000 troops were involved and the two armies lost about 70,000 casualties. It was the single bloodiest day of the entire Napoleonic Wars period — "Bloody Monday".

Using the game engine from Moscow '41 (and not VNG's Waterloo 200), the game Bloody Monday provides action and challenges, plus the joy of die rolling. Unlike other VNG products, Bloody Monday uses large 20mm blocks to provide enough detail and different unit types but still keep the game playable in one sitting. Colorful PVC stickers and "fog of war" give players everything they need in an easy mechanism.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet

Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
A super-simple and addictive game where players have to transfer the symbols rolled to the grid of the block sheet. The more identical symbols are grouped, the more points can be scored. The game is as simple as Sudoku and can also be played alone.
How it is played:
2 dice are rolled and each player has to draw these symbols into their sheet following very simple rules:
- the two symbols have to be drawn in orthogonally adjacent fields. (Single fields previously surrounded with symbols will never be filled.)
- as long as there are adjacent spaces, the symbols must be entered.
The game ends when the sheets are filled or there are no legal adjacent spaces left. Each row and column are scored separately: 2, 3, 4 or 5 adjacent symbols of the same type score 2, 3, 4, 5 points PLUS 4/5 bonus points for 4/5 symbols.

The Grail Games edition of Criss Cross also includes "Advanced" rules which add a layer of complexity to the base game.

name.value: The Quick and the Dead: Coastal Actions in WWII

item.description:
Description from the publisher:

The Quick and the Dead (Q&D) is meant to replicate the sharp, short actions involving coastal forces during World War II. More specifically, this set of rules and cards is focused on the fighting between coastal forces in the Mediterranean Sea, but if the rules prove popular, expansions for the English Channel and the Pacific theater are planned. It is important to recognize, however, that these rules focus on only a part of the operation of coastal forces. Coastal actions are characterized by patrolling and stealth, usually at night, punctuated by a quick, violent engagement at close quarters, often less than 500 yards.

Quick and the Dead features a unique diceless and turnless system in which players delcare and play action cards as fast as they can. This creates an unusual tunnel vision phenomenon in which players are focused on the actions of their small craft and can be surprised when an enemy comes alongside and opens fire. Games usually last between 30 and 45 minutes, so you can play two or three in an evening.

PT-boat actions are generally divided into three phases. There is the stealthy approach phase in which one force lies in wait, trying to get an advantageous position on the enemy. This phase can last several hours, beginning from the time the boats leave port until (and if) contact is made with the enemy. There is the assault phase, in which the boats battle each other, typically at fewer than 200 yards, and nearly always at night. This phase usually lasts between 20 and 40 minutes. Finally, there is the aftermath. Typically one side or the other affects a disengagement and both sides head from home.

The Quick and the Dead focuses on the middle phase. Games last about 40 minutes. There are no turns and no chart cards. Players use cards to control the movement and firing of their boats. All the needed information is on the cards. When a player has exhausted his cards, each of his boats makes a morale check, draws more cards, and continues playing. At the end of a game, players feel exhausted, as if they've just been through a fight.

If you like your naval games pedantic and chart-ridden, The Quick and the Dead is not for you. If you want to feel as if you've actually been in a PT fight, these are the only rules that give you that feeling. The game plays very different than most game you've played. Some players get the hang of the fluid, no-turns system quickly. Others have difficulty. I have found that by a player's third game, they get the hang of it. Many don't like the game the first time they play, but after playing a couple more times, really enjoy it. During play tests some have suggested that I should include an optional standard-style turn sequence. While players would be free to do so, I've decided not to include a tradtional turn sequence, because then The Quick and the Dead would be just another game, and I wanted it to be unique.

The Quick and the Dead comes with a rulebook, the cards to play the game, scenario cards, and boat record cards for most of the German, Italian, British, and American boat types in the Mediterranean. I usually play on a 4'x6' table, but that's for a six-player game. You could certainly play on a dining room table. The basic set of cards is for that size game. The advantage of the .pdf format is that if you want to player larger games (more players) you can print another deck of cards.

From the back cover
Wellington Rules is a set of rules designed to fight tactical engagements during the Napoleonic Wars. Wellington Rules is designed so that each player would control approximately a brigade of troops. 
In Wellington Rules players command brigades and divisions in small tactical actions of the Napoleonic Wars. Players will find that Wellington Rules makes the command of these elements challenging and fun while the streamlined, consistent mechanics makes the game easy to learn and simple to play. With Wellington Rules you can concentrate on tactics, not charts.

name.value: Big Battles for Little Hands: Wargaming Source Book for Children

item.description:
Description from the back of the book:

This book is an introduction to the hobby of playing tabletop battles with miniatures. This a fun, interesting and educational pastime for children of all ages. This book traces its roots from games played by H.G. Wells and R.L. Stevenson in their backyards around the turn of the century.
Big Battles is meant to be a sourcebook, a great deal of information has been packed into it. Big Battles for Little Hands includes:

An introduction to wargamming

A brief history of land warfare

A primer on tactics

A complete set of rules for playing battles: Milk and Cookie Rules

A complete set of rules for playing skirmishes: Blood and Swash

Scenarios

Guides on where to find model soldiers

An introductory guide on how to paint soldiers

A guide for parents

and much more...

Beer and Pretzels Urban Combat (B.A.P.U.C.) is a simple, fast-playing skirmish war game using modern small arms in a hypothetical future of civilian urban warfare, using a card based turn sequence. Players agree on the size of each army made up of urban guerillas (typical scenario calls for any guerilla troop of five to eleven guerillas, though enough tokens are available to field 18 guerillas per side). Players also agree on weapon equipment ranging from pistols to machine guns and grenade launchers. Using a shuffled deck of standard playing cards, turns are determined by the draw of the cards – red cards allow the red force to move, while black cards allow the blue force to move.
Combat is based on the individual guerilla with a health of four points each.
Optional rules include Personalized Guerilla leaders, each with their own special rules.
Six scenarios are provided with the game, each with their own victory condition and rules for the scenario. One of the scenarios is designed for four players, while the largest scenario (22 guerillas in combat) plays in about 30 minutes.

Rules are only five pages long and includes double-sides reference chart for weapons and movement effects, two additional pages of optional rules, a diagram illustrating valid attacks, and a sheet containing the six scenarios. The game comes with a preprinted hex-based game map and an uncut token sheet for fire effects and guerillas for both red and blue forces.

Eliminate the opponent's pieces by mastering a shrinking and transforming playing area, and tiles that fix the type of movement of the pieces.

In turn, each player moves one of his pawns, then removes from play the tile his pawn was placed on. If the removed tile creates an empty space in the playing area, the player moves either side of the row or column to form an uninterrupted row or column. If this reconstruction creates an empty space again, he can move either side of the row or column again and so on. The capture of an opposing pawn is done by moving to the tile it occupies. The winner is the player who captures all 4 opposing pawns.

Contains:

36 tiles,
 8 wooden pawns,
 1 rule booklet.

name.value: The Battle of the River Plate

item.description:
The Battle of the River Plate is a tactical game of the December 13, 1939, engagement between the German cruiser Admiral Graf Spee and its British pursuers, the Ajax, Achilles, and Exeter. Components consist of a rules booklet, a Combat Card, four ship-armor diagram cards, plastic blocks labeled as the ships, wooden blocks in several colors, and eight dice.

The game is intended to be played on a hex board supplied by the owner. The rules specify use of an Avalon Hill Stalingrad board so that starting hexes can be specified in terms of Stalingrad locations. Pieces use both hexes and hexsides for movement to double the number of possible facing directions.

Movement is plotted and executed simultaneously. Rules cover gunfire, torpedoes, smokescreens, and ammunition supply. There is no time limit; play continues until the Graf Spee escapes or is sunk.

The stated purpose of the game is to "introduce the designers method of naval combat". Five years later Bruce Moore published the better known game Early Pacific Battles.

name.value: Monopoly Junior: Eloise's Rawther Exciting Globetrotting Adventure

item.description:
Description from the back of the box:

Join Eloise, Weenie, and Skipperdee on a globetrotting adventure around the world. You'll visit Eloise's favorite cities - Paris, Moscow, and of course New York, and learn lots of interesting facts about landmarks and famous places.

Along the way you can buy famous properties, put up penthouses and of course say "Charge It Please" when someone comes to visit.

The player who collects the most money at the end of the trip wins.

Recreation of a soccer game.
Teams are formed by 11 players.
Rules are simple. 
Game for 2 players.
Field is divided into square areas.
There is a maximun number of players allowed per area.
Passes, driblings and shots to goal are checked by a die roll.
In advanced game there are action points for movement, an for dribbling.

A multicolored collecting game for 2-4 players.

Each caterpillar has a headpart and a tailpart.
Shuffle up the 6 different colored bodyparts.
Roll the die and match the color of the visible bodypart.
If it match, add the bodypart to your caterpillar.
Or wait untill next turn.

Who can complete his caterpillar, with 6 different bodyparts, first and wins the game?

A variant of the traditional Japanese card game 'Hanafuda', this deck of cards is specifically designed for the Hawaiian Style game known as 'Sakura'. Two to six people can play, either individually or as teams of two.

The 48 cards are divided into twelve 'hiki' or suits, each corresponding to a specific month. The four cards in each hiki have 20, 10, 5, and zero points. The objective of the game is to accumulate the most points by matching cards. The highest possible score is 240 points.

After shuffling and cutting the deck, the 'oya' (dealer) deals cards counter-clockwise to the players; the number of cards dealt differs depending on the number of players. The oya then plays a number of cards in the center of the table, known as the "field". The remainder of the deck is set nearby as a draw stack.

Play begins with the oya and moves counter-clockwise. The player draws a card from her hand and places it in the field. If the played card matches the hiki (suit) of a card in the field, the player places her card on top of the matching card to show everyone the match. She then picks up both cards and places them face-up in a "points section" in front of her. She discards any cards with no value in the 'kasu' (rubbish) pile behind the draw stack.

Next, the player draws one card from the draw stack. If it matches a card in the field, she must take the pair of cards. Otherwise, the card is left in the field. This ends that player's turn. It is possible that a player may capture as many as four cards per turn.

The player to the right takes the next turn. Play continues in this fashion until all the cards have been used in each player's hand. Points are then totaled.

Advanced play adds a wild card and also 'yaku' (bonus combinations) in special three-card combinations that are scored at the end of the game. Holding one or more yaku causes the other players to deduct points from their score, rather than adding points to the yaku-player's score.

Description from the publisher (translated):
It's party time in the jungle! Build a pyramid, play skittles, throw and catch, ... .. take up these and many more little challenges to win medals. A first action game to get young children handling objects and developing their fine motor skills.

Preparing to play:
Place the six animals in the middle of the table next to base of the box and the medals. Shuffle the cards then place them in a pile face down next to the box.

How:
Players are entitled to three attempts for each challenge. The challenge is pointed out with a card.

If you succeed at a challenge, you win a medal, otherwise you do not win anything.

Who wins?
When all the medals have been won, the winner is the player with the most medals.

There are six challenges: As an example we will explain one challenge.

Challenge 1: The pyramid. 
Take the two animals shown on the card and try to stack them 
as illustrated in the picture. The pyramid needs to stay standing for at least 30 seconds in order to count.

Description from the publisher (translated):
¡Es la hora de la fiesta en la selva! Construir una pirámide, jugar a los bolos, lanzar y atrapar... Una serie de pequeños desafíos para ganar medallas. Un primer juego de acción, manipulación y destreza destinado a los más pequeños.

Preparación: 
Se colocan los seis animales en el centro de la mesa junto a las medallas y el fondo de la caja. Se barajan las cartas y se apilan boca abajo junto a la caja.

Cómo: 
Los jugadores pueden efectuar tres intentos para cumplir
cada desafío. Los retos están señalados en cada carta.
Si logra cumplir el desafío, el jugador gana una medalla. Si no, no gana nada. A continuación, le toca al jugador siguiente.
 ¿Quién gana?
Una vez distribuidas todas las medallas, gana el jugador que tiene la mayor cantidad.

Hay 6 desafíos. Como ejemplo explicamos el reto nº 1.
Desafío 1: la pirámide. 
El jugador toma los dos animales de la carta e intenta superponerlos como se indica en ella. La pirámide debe mantenerse durante 30 segundos como mínimo para ser validada.

link.value: Board Game Parfait (ボードゲームパフェ)

item.description:
Based on an online word game, 'Text Twist' challenges players to make as many words as possible out of a given set of letters within a 2 minute period.

A game consists of 5 rounds. During each round, a card is drawn which lists a series of letters. Information is given on the card detailing how many possible 3,4,5,6 and 7 letter words can be created from that specific mix of letters. Players write the letters on their individual dry erase board, then the timer is flipped and players have 2 minutes to produce as many words as possible. At the end of the 2 minutes, players score points for valid words created (a booklet is included listing all possible words from each combination of letters). The score for that round is recorded, and the next round begins with a new set of letters. After 5 rounds, the player with the highest score wins.

The game can be played as a solo puzzle challenge.

Contents:
4 wipe-off Answer/Score boards
1 Instruction/Solutions booklet
144 cards (864 challenges!)
4 dry-erase markers
1 2-minute timer

name.value: Stock Trader: The Stock Market Board Game

item.description:
Your rich uncle just gave you some investments. Can you make some smart moves and turn them into a fortune?

Stock Trader is a simple and fun stock market game that you can play solo or with the whole family. Do you have what it takes to be a smart investor on the stock exchange? Find out with Stock Trader, The Stock Market Board Game!

The objective of the game is to become the richest player by buying and selling stocks and gold. Buy low, and sell high!

The main board tracks the value of each investment. The value of each investment is increased or decreased by rolling dice each turn, if the positive die (green) is higher than the negative die (red), the value moves up that many spaces. If the red die is greater than the green die, the value drops and could even crash that stock completely! Each turn there is a new 'Headline News' card that can affect the stock values in addition to the dice rolls.

After the dice are rolled and the values set, each player decides what they would like to buy and sell and tracks their shares on their own 'Portfolio' card.

After 10-turns, everyone sells their investments and the player with the most money wins the game!

A Co-operative Game with an emergency-room simulation theme.

Gameplay is cooperative. Players are all on the same team and take turns being team leader. Players take decisions on who to admit to an emergency room bed, how to distribute limited resources of skilled personnel to address injuries. Game mechanisms control the flow of patients, nurses, doctors and time. Beds are limited, injuries vary from critical to nominal. Patients have varied age range and varied gender/appearence.

The goal is to treat as many patients in one 8-hour shift as possible. Players do not win or lose, but treating all 15 patients is a perfect game, leaving some patients for the next shift is to be avoided if possible.

My Booty! is a speed and dexterity game for 2 to 4 players.
Each round, a set of lookout cards is revealed, then players must try to be the first to push forward the appropriate pirate tokens in front of them and slap on the treasure chest tile to score points.

Different lookout cards call for different pirate tokens. Act quickly, but don't twist your brain!
Be the best and fastest pirate on the sea and enjoy some chaotic fun!

City Development game

game-play
Each turn draw a map tile, and place it with others map tile(s). If the map tiles form a 2/3 circle, you can draw a extra map tile from supply. 
Then for each circle you form, you can gain 1 building tiles. 
You can change city cards by building tiles.

goal
Be the first player collect 3 city cards.

Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
In 8 Out Of 10 Cats, players or teams take turns answering questions on opinion polls, surveys and statistics.

There are five different categories of questions, including "Poll with a Hole", "And the Winner Is ...", and "Pick of the Polls". Players roll a die in order to determine which kind of question they have to answer. Once a player or team has correctly answered ten questions, they have to successfully answer an "8 Out Of 10 Stats" card to win (and end) the game.

Join the dynamic action embedded in the turbulent times of World War II. The heroic struggle, full of sacrifices and tough decisions will make even you fail to notice how much you consume climate unpredictable clashes on the battlefield. Take on the role of an all-powerful commander and lead your troops on the way to victory.

Autarcha is an innovative strategy, which compete with each other two parties to the conflict. Rich in variants of tactical gameplay makes every time we experience a meeting with the game again. Enhanced combat system and countless possibilities are distinguishing features of the product. Trust us and let yourself be drawn into a new world of Autarcha.

The game takes place on the board, on which are marked various landscape elements: land, forest, mountains, rivers and cities. The board is perforated by transport links, such as road and rail. Each of these elements can be used in the game: Rail and road allow faster transport, forest and mountains hide the army and the cause that they are difficult to destroy, and the water stops, eg. Armor or artillery, which they can not overcome these obstacles. It depends on the player how to use elements of the board.

Most important is the general staff - in most scenarios, the destruction ensures victory. It represents the player and can give orders to the other four types of units:

Infantry - cheap unit with a relatively small range. Easy to recruit and rapid implementation to fight.
Sappers - a specialized unit performing special operations, eg. Putting min, which in turn are invisible to the enemy
Panzer - unit with a high cost, but high mobility in the field and long range.
Artillery - a unit of positional far, code coverage.
Branches can attack at a distance in their moves during the turn.

The game is included economic aspect, each player can build infantry and sappers in the city and armored units and artillery in our factory.

The game can be started in a simple way - choose the same set of units for each player, set them on the board and start the fight.

item.description: In Hollywood Boulevard, players are theater owners tasked with picking films that will generate more money than any of their competitors. Each turn represents one week wherein films will be played. Each film will generate money by rolling dice. The more dice, usually the more money. There are various methods of gaining more dice for the films. Advertising, amenities, and chance cards will add to the amount of dice rolled.
